Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the principal functions of language is to manage social relationships. Yet much of our current language technology fails to account for how language varies across social contexts, or how it depends on speakers' attitudes and identities. As a consequence, existing language technology is brittle to variation, particularly in non-standard dialects and informal social contexts. This CAREER project is aimed at closing this gap, by building data-driven computational algorithms and representations that are capable of identifying social meaning in large corpora of text and speech. The scope of the research includes local social variables, such as the address terms used to modulate formality in conversation ("Ms", "dude"), as well as group-level dialect differences across large communities. The expected results of the research include: (1) new computational methods for studying language's social function and, correspondingly, new insights; (2) leveraging these insights to enable new computational linguistic applications, and to improve the robustness of existing technology; (3) better engagement between computer science and the social sciences in augmenting the tools that researchers require in order to access large-scale naturally occurring social and linguistic data; and (4) improved education on the analysis and interpretation of such data for undergraduate and graduate students and the public at large.

This project uses unsupervised structure induction techniques to identify the latent structures that connect linguistic and social phenomena. Sociolinguistic structures can be mined from a diverse array of data sources, including social media and digitized humanities archives. The project aims at interactions between linguistic and social phenomena on multiple levels of detail: (1) macro-level sociolinguistic structures, such as the intersecting social identities that drive dialect variation; (2) micro-level sociolinguistic structures, such as the array of address terms that modulate formality in dialogue; and (3) dynamic sociolinguistic structures, such as the transmission of new words, orthographies, and syntactic constructions across social media. Identifying these sociolinguistic structures requires new learning algorithms and representations, driven by theoretical insights from the social sciences. The findings of this project are disseminated in venues that target both the computational and social science communities, and the outreach and education components include building new bridges between these communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-sponsored project "Sociolinguistic Structure Induction" aimed to forge new connections between computational linguistics and sociolinguistics, with the research goals of (1) better understanding the diversity and dynamism of human language and (2) making language technology more robust to the challenges that this diversity and dynamism pose. In addition, the project aimed to build new cross-disciplinary communities and educational platforms. The project delivered on these goals through a series of research advances, peer-reviewed publications, educational initiatives, and outreach programs. Some highlights include:

New computational models unifying language and social network structures. These models show that it is possible to make natural language processing more accurate by leveraging social signals (e.g., Yang et al. 2016; Yang and Eisenstein 2017, Han and Eisenstein 2019), and show how computational techniques can offer new insights on language variation (e.g., Krishnan and Eisenstein 2015) and change (e.g., Goel et al. 2016; Stewart and Eisenstein 2018).
New computational approaches to fundamental questions in sociolinguistics, focusing particularly on how individuals modulate their language use according to the social context (e.g., Pavalanathan and Eisenstein 2015; Pavalanathan et al 2017; Kiesling et al 2018), and on how languages change (e.g., Stewart and Eisenstein 2018). Many of these works were published in top-tier venues in linguistics, and were co-authored with collaborators from the social sciences and digital humanities, demonstrating the interdisciplinary impact of the research.
New connections between computational sociolinguistics and social computing, with particular emphasis to how social media platforms can maintain norms and preserve healthy online communities (e.g., Chandrasekharan et al 2018a, Chandrasekharan et al 2018b, Pavalanathan et al. 2018; Stewart et al 2017). Beyond social computing, the project also demonstrated connections to scientometrics (the science of science; Soni et al 2020) and the digital humanities (Soni et al 2019; Soni et al forthcoming).
Interdisciplinary community-building, through the co-founding of a workshop on Natural Language Processing and Computational Social Science, the creation of a doctoral fellowship and mentorship program at the same workshop, and the Atlanta Computational Social Science workshop.
Education and outreach, through the creation of a new graduate course on Computational Social Science, two public tutorials on computational analysis of language change (at NAACL and IC2S2 2019). In addition, the project sponsored the doctoral research of four PhD students at Georgia Tech.
